title-group.article-title: Cement dust pollution induces toxicity or deficiency of some essential elements in wild plants growing around a cement factory

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Biology, Erzincan University, Erzincan, Turkey

abstract.p: In the present study, it was aimed to determine the effects of cement dust pollution on contents of some significant essential elements (P, S, K, Ca, Fe and Cl) in wild plants (Medigago varia, Anchusa leptophylla, Euphorbia orientalis, Lactuca serriola, Artemisia spicigera, Crambe orientalis, Convolvulus sepium and Senecio vernalis) using wavelength-dispersive spectrometer X-ray fluorescence technique. Plant samples were collected from different locations around a cement factory which is located at Askale about 50 km from Erzurum (Turkey). The element contents in the plant specimens that existed in both 0–100 m (dense dusted) and 2000 m (undusted) areas were compared. P, S, K and Cl contents were found to be high in the plants growing in areas 0–100 m from the cement factory, compared to same plants at 2000 m far from the factory. However, Ca and Fe contents were determined to be low in plants growing in 0–100 m area from the factory. Results of the study can contribute to understand how mineral deficiency and toxicity lead to detrimental effects on plant growth and development in the fields contaminated by cement dust.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: As the population of the world increases, the need of housing rises as well. The cement industry grows too. This industry has a major role in the instability of the environment and produces many air pollution hazards (Stern, 1976). Cement dust falling on soil causes a shift in pH to alkaline side and a reduction in quality of soils (Bayhan et al., 2002; Iqbal and Shafug, 2001). In addition, the atmosphere polluted by cement factories has been known to include high levels of heavy metals such as fluoride, magnesium, lead, cadmium, nickel zinc, copper and beryllium (Ade-Ademilua and Umebese, 2007; Isikli et al., 2006). The heavy metals present in the cement dust play an important role in disturbing the various metabolic processes in plants (Borka, 1986) and thus lead to detrimental effects on the growth and development of plants (Abdullah and Iqbal, 1991; Gupta and Mishra, 1994; Iqbal and Shafug, 2001; Prasad and Inamdar, 1990; Uysal et al., 2003). In recent studies, it was determined that cement dust pollution played an important role in the variation of wild and aquatic plant species and their antioxidative enzyme systems (Erdal and Demirtas, 2010; Mutlu et al., 2009). Although studies provide intriguing insights into the mode of action of cement dust pollution on plants, the overall picture remains highly fragmented, for example, the effects of cement dust pollution on the uptake and content of essential elements in plants are unknown.

The recent advent of commercially available wavelength-dispersive spectrometers for X-ray fluorescence (XRF) measurements has provided an economical and powerful tool for environmental, clinical, chemical, geological and industrial analyses (Demir et al., 2006, 2008). XRF is a nondestructive, fast, multielement technique for analyzing the surface layer and determining major, as well as minor elements, in thin and thick samples of all sizes and forms. Accurate quantitative measurements, however, often depend on matrix correction procedures, which require a large number of standards. A wide range of new research applications have been demonstrated using the energy-dispersive X-ray fluorescence technique (Dumlupinar et al., 2007; Karabulut and Budak, 2000; Karabulut et al., 2005).

In this study, it was aimed to determine the effects of cement dust pollution on the content of some essential elements (P, S, K, Ca, Fe and Cl) of wild plants (Medigago varia, Anchusa leptophylla, Euphorbia orientalis, Lactuca serriola, Artemisia spicigera, Crambe orientalis, Convolvulus sepium and Senecio vernalis) using wavelength-dispersive spectrometer X-ray fluorescence (WDXRF), a new technique for biological materials. This technique is indispensable if accurate and fast elemental analysis is needed, as when controlling a melt in a steel works or the raw mix at a cement plant. One reason for its popularity in these applications is that its ease of use; and the ruggedness of the equipment allows quality results to be obtained in plant conditions by operators without advanced analytical skills (Dumlupinar et al., 2011; Genisel et al., 2011; Norman, 2004).

sec.title: Apparatus
Study area and plant materials
sec.p: Plant samples were collected from different locations around a cement factory, which is located at Askale about 50 km from Erzurum (Turkey). In July 2007, 8 wild plant species were collected from the area 2000 m away from the outer zone of the cement factory. Then, samples of the same plant species were collected from the outer zone of the cement factory that is between 0 and 100 m areas. The leaves collected from all plants were quickly transported to laboratory in thermoses including ice, and then they were stored in a deep freezer (−30°C) until analyses. These species collected were checked with voucher specimens deposited in Ata Herbarium at the Department of Biology, Science Faculty, Atatürk University, Erzurum, Turkey. Leaves with similar ages were removed from the plants studied. The essential elements (P, S, K, Ca, Fe and Cl) of plant specimens existed in both 0–100 m and 2000 m areas were compared.

sec.title: Sample preparation
sec.p: Plant samples from both the areas were washed with deionized water before analysis in order to exclude superficial contamination by cement dust. After drying at 60°C to a constant weight, the dry leaf tissues were ground by hand in a ceramic mortar. They were homogenized with liquid nitrogen to make the samples as homogenous as possible. The samples were then transferred onto a 3-cm diameter disc of polyethylene Mylar film. The matrix effects and their inaccurate correction are usually absent. The background count rate, which is mainly due to scatters in the sample matrix, increases with sample thickness, and therefore the detection limit which is extrapolated for thick samples in similar counting conditions is less favorable, particularly for elements with low atomic numbers. A sample thickness of less than 0.001 g/cm2 has been chosen as a reasonable compromise between saturation thickness and optimal peak-to-background ratios. To obtain a XRF-mylar film, a small metallic sample holder made of aluminum with a diameter of about 3.0 cm was used (Dumlupinar et al., 2007).

sec.title: Measurements
sec.p: WDXRF was used for analysis of the semiqualitative method. The measurements were performed using a ZSX 100e sequential spectrometer equipped with an Rh X-ray tube. sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: All measurements were performed three times and the average of the values was used. Statistical analysis was performed using one-way analysis of variance and the means were compared using the Student’s t test for two independent samples (p ≤ 0.05).

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: Previous research put forth that pollution originated from cement factory led to a noticeable increase in lime, exchangeable cation, pH and electrical conductivity with a decrease in organic matter content and field capacity in the dusted soils (Bayhan et al., 2002). In addition, it was reported that pollution derived from cement factories had a detrimental effect on the growth of most plants (Borka, 1986; Iqbal and Shafug, 2001; Prasad and Inamdar, 1990; Uysal et al., 2003). Some research also determined a reduction in the number of species around the heavily polluted cement industrial units (Mutlu et al., 2009; Shafiq and Iqbal, 1987) and remarkable alterations in diversity and antioxidant enzyme activities of wild and aquatic plants around cement factory (Erdal and Demirtas, 2010; Mutlu et al., 2009).

In this study, we determined the effects of cement dust pollution on the content of the essential elements (P, S, K, Ca, Fe and Cl) of the wild plants (M. varia, A. leptophylla, E. orientalis, L. serriola, A. spicigera, C. orientalis, C. sepium and S. vernalis). These plants were collected from the outer zone of the cement factory that is between 0 and 100 m areas (Askale, Erzurum). It was compared with the data obtained from plant samples which are grown 0-100 m around the factory and the data obtained from plant samples which are grown 2000 m away from the factory.

Calcium (Ca) content was found to be low in 6 species (Anogramma leptopylla, L. serriola, A. spicigera, Caecilia oriantalis, Eleutherodactylus oriantalis and M. varia) of the plants growing in areas 0–100 m from the cement factory, compared to the samples of the same plants obtained from 2000 m away from the factory but was determined to be high in C. sepium and unchanged in S. vernalis (Figure 1). It is well known that high levels of some cations such as magnesium, ammonium, iron, aluminum and especially potassium reduce the calcium uptake in some crops (Hepler and Wayne, 1985; Rao et al., 2006). Therefore, in the present study the decrease in Ca content can be attributed to the increase in K content (Figures 1 and 2). Ca deficiency is very rare if pH is maintained properly. The deficiency symptoms first appear in growing tips and young leaves because of low mobility of Ca. The tips and young leaves become chlorotic followed by necrosis (plant tissue death) of leaf margins. Calcium deficiency induces premature shedding of fruit and buds (Rao et al., 2006).

sec.p: Iron (Fe) content in 5 plant species (A. leptophylla, S. vernalis, C. orientalis, E. orientalis and C. sepium) collected from the areas between 0 and 100 m of the cement factory was determined to be at a low level, while it was high in the other 3 species (L. serriola, A. spicigera and M. varia; Figure 3). Fe content in plant tissues is about 100 ppm of dry matter (Brown et al., 1991). Fe deficiency is a worldwide phenomena in crop production on calcareous soils (contain enough free CaCO3). Deficiency symptoms first appear on young leaves, which show interveinal chlorosis (chlorophyll destruction; Taiz and Zeiger, 2002). Fe toxicity may cause bronzing, stunted top and root growth (Pushnik and Miller, 1989; Rao et al., 2006). In another study, it was found that there was positive correlation between the levels of Ca and Fe in plants near the cement factory (Semhi et al., 2010). However, some elements like calcium, zinc, manganese, phosphorus or copper can tie up iron if they are present in high amounts. A similar result is also determined in our study (Figures 1, 3 and 5).

sec.p: Potassium (K) content was found to be high in all the plants growing in areas between 0 and 100 m of the cement factory, compared to the same plants growing at 2000 m away from the factory (Figure 2). K plays a pivotal role in plant growth and development (Taiz and Zeiger, 2002). K is also essential for protein synthesis and activates nearly 45 enzymes involved in various metabolic processes (Mengel, 1997). K is required in 2–5% of dry weight of plants. K toxicity may occur if the tissue concentration is more than 10% in the dry matter (Rao et al., 2006). It is known that K toxicity induces Fe deficiency and, hence, causes symptoms such chlorosis (Mehreban et al., 2008; Sahrawat, 2004). The result from our study is in good agreement with these studies (Figure 2). Therefore, in the present study the decrease in Ca concentration could be attributed to an increase in K concentrations (Figures 1 and 2).

Chlorine (Cl) content was found to be high in all species of the plants growing in areas between 0 and 100 m from the cement factory, compared to the same plants growing at 2000 m away from the factory (Figure 4). The percentage increase in Cl was mostly much more than 40%. In addition, all the plants having a high K concentration had interestingly a high Cl percentage (Figures 2 and 4). Plants usually contain chloride in the range of 2–20 mg/g dry matter, although the chlorine requirement for optimal growth is in the range of 0.20–0.40 mg/g dry weight (Critchley, 1985; Fixen, 1993). Cl is available to plants from several sources like soil reserves, rain, irrigation water, fertilizers and through air pollution (Coleman et al., 1987). Therefore, there is much concern about chloride toxicity rather than deficiency in plants. Cl toxicity is a worldwide phenomenon and is an important factor limiting plant growth (Rao et al., 2006).

Phosphorus (P) content was found to be high in 6 species (A. leptophylla, E. orientalis, A. spicigera, C. orientalis, C. sepium and S. vernalis) of the plants growing in areas between 0–100 m from the cement factory, however, it was found to be low in M. varia compared to the four respective controls. However, its concentration was not changed in L. serriola (Figure 5). P is the second important nutrient required by plants (Taiz and Zeiger, 2002). P is present in the soil in inorganic and organic forms. Much of the inorganic P is present mainly as H2PO4 (Rao et al., 2006). The requirement of phosphorus for optimal growth is in the range of 0.3–0.5% of the plant dry matter. The toxicity may occur if the tissue concentration is more than 1% of dry matter (Lauer et al., 1989). P toxicity symptoms are generally an inhibition of growth, accelerated leaf senescence (Marschner, 1995), impaired leaf water relations (Bhatti and Loneragen, 1970) and induced micronutrient deficiency (Marschner, 1995). In some plants, this toxicity appears as brown-gray necrosis on young leaves, stunted growth, leaf rosetting, chlorosis in younger leaves and interveinal chlorosis (Marschner, 1995). The toxic level of P induces deficiency of Fe and Ca but toxicity of Cl, S and K (Figures 1
–6). These results are consistent with the previous studies (Franco-Zorrilla et al., 2004; Hammond et al., 2003; Hawkins et al., 2008; Wang et al., 2002).

caption.p: Effects of cement dust pollution on S concentration in wild plants growing around the cement factory. *Indicates a significant difference according to the Student’s t test for two independent samples (p ≤ 0.05).

sec.p: Likewise, sulfur (S) content of 6 plants in the factory area of 0–100 m was high while that of A. leptophylla and S. vernalis were low as compared to the respective controls (Figure 6). The most important source of sulfur is SO4 −2 taken up by roots (Saito, 2000). Sulfur is required at a concentration of 0.1–0.5% of dry weight of plants for optimal growth. Plant growth is adversely affected if SO4 −2 concentration is more than 50 mM as found in some saline soils (Leustek and Saito, 1999). The reduced growth rate and dark-green color of leaves are the characteristic features of sulfur toxicity (Rao et al., 2006; Taiz and Zeiger, 2002). At below toxic levels, the plants are able to utilize SO2. S assimilation and biomass production are correlated with SO2 in the polluted air (Rennenberg, 1984). S toxicity leads to visible effects that include chlorosis, necrosis and long-term yield reduction (Brychkova et al., 2007; Legge and Krupa, 2002; Noji et al., 2001).

In conclusion, while it was found that the contents of P, S, K and Cl to be high, that of Ca and Fe were determined to be low in plants growing in the factory area of 0-100 m (dusted area) from, compared to the same plants growing at 2000 m (undusted area) away from the factory. The results of this study can contribute to understand that the deficiency of essential element and toxicity lead to detrimental effects on plant growth and development in the fields contaminated by cement dust.
